allScrap.description: If it weren't for it's bioluminescent properties, it would have been impossible to find this hunk of such an invaluable material. But there it is, glowing faintly, begging to be wrought into something fabulous.

Not much but a chassis left, but what else do you need? Just the frame is worth ten times the weight of it. And when it was whole? Well, you'd probably never even know it had blown past if it weren't for the small sandstorm it kicked up.
The fact that computations were once done mechanically is hard to wrap your head around when they've been completed my air molecules for the past few centuries.
The Bamak make awful big ships for being as small as they are.

You'd think something so massive would have even one recognizable trait or insignia, but neither of you have any idea what this thing is. All you know is it's big, and it'll make for a nice payout if it can be brought back to the outpost.
Whoever made this clearly didn't want anyone finding it. Being covered in light-absorbing paint in the middle of a desert, however, it stands out like a cartoon hole to nowhere.
It might just be the wind but you swear the empty shaft is still humming.

allScrap.scrapName: Dazzak City public air tram car
allScrap.description: The model of the car suggests it's relatively new. Why it's laying in a valley of dunes is anyone's guess.
Something this massive shouldn't be possible. Even in the never ending wastes that surround it, this rusting hulk of a freighter ship looms large. A mighty haul if you can get it moving.
Why something as universal as a fuel pump appears so rarely does give one pause.
CH1-P looks at the box for a moment wondering if they're ready to try out a new voice but decides against it before tossing it into the cargo bay.

allScrap.scrapName: Countenance frigate heads up display module
allScrap.description: How CH1-P was able to identify this lump of glass and circuitry so quickly gives Hasron pause before they load it into the storage bay.
You've never seen an intergalactic carrier so bedecked with analogue audio systems before. Hasron reckons it made a whole lot of noise in its day.
After standing gobsmacked for several moments, you both realize that you are about to become much more wealthy.

CH1-P has always been trouble by the fact that the galaxy's militaries always seem contract the best designers. EIT configurations might inspire fear around the system, but at least they look cool as all hell doing it.
CH1-P recalls seeing these on their second stop in exile. Strange machines. They turn the clouds into liquid to ferry off somewhere else, and always when you were hoping for a rainy day.
Why these were ever allowed to exist is anyone's guess. The fact that some planets still use them has made it easy for travellers to know what parts of the galaxy to avoid.
There are many farmers who feel this is exactly the state and location in which all weather satellites should be.
Not many of these have survived from the old days, and only the decrepit and reviled barons of those times were sad to see them go.

Moving water has long been one of organic life's greatest fascinations. The engineering evident in the piston is a testament to that fascination so precisely it has been crafted, and yet to what end it's impossible to tell.
CH1-P flinches as they pull the small core from its sand blasted casing. Prying out brains is never pleasant, even for someone who turned their back on the Machine Worlds.

CH1-P wonders what kind of lives got lived in there and wonders if their personal data was transferred before it made its way to the canyons. Three might still be diaries of bored travelers and unrequited lovers waiting to be resurrected.
One has to wonder how something meant to be so immovable made its way down from the highways and wormholes. Then again the waste haulers have moved much that was never meant to be shifted.
Counter to popular belief, the woon cannons do not summon beings from alternate planes of existence.
The WD-40k is beloved by any scrap buyer who knows a deal when they see one. Nothing crushes quite like it.
Never designed to be terrestrial, it's almost sad to see it so far from the vast expanse of black it was meant for.
Hasron pulls on a pair of thick rubber gloves before prying out the resonator from it's chamber. Electrocution is the leading cause of death for terrestrial scrappers, or so they've been told.

If you've ever met someone from Galatan V you'll hear horror stories about these things. The entire planetary government ran on them for about 200 standard years and their techs stopped being able to interface with them for the latter 100.
The Paranti don't get around much but they hear more than either of you could know exists. If this thing were operational, you'd never have known it existed.

As soon as the decimator's form is lifted from the soft sands of the dune CH1-P's face goes slack. It was not uncommon for the Machine Captains to employ such devices when bringing a new inhabited planet into their ranks.
Drifters are well known for their lack of propulsion, which makes it odd that a vessel with so much drifter iconography is sporting three racks of ion thrusters and a heavy cannon.
Brushing the sand off the side of the machine, Hasron squints as the rays of Daru reflect off the burnished surface.

The weathered exterior of the metallic mass makes you questions how it would ever have been able to maintain orbit, let along the transfer of data. But once upon a time you know it was new and smooth.

Beloved by smugglers everywhere, Hasron and CH1-P are careful examining the craft. They find half a dozen traps before realizing the whole thing would have exploded right away if it weren't for a handful of wires that appear to have been chewed through by some small, benevolent creature.
It takes Hasron a few moments before they realize what they're looking at. But the smell that rolls up from the damp sand under their haul makes it evident enough.
Every small lightspeed craft needs an accelerator ring, but what excellerates the exerator?
You never know what might end up out here. That thing belongs in a museum, but it's worth its weight in scrap all the same.
Not much better than a couple of tin cans and a cord of ebruliam hair.
If it weren't for the fact that the generator was in a few thousand scattered pieces Hasron would have loved to relive a few childhood holospace favorites.

Space elevators were very popular in some parts of the galaxy until word got out that one of the largest suppliers of the structures had been using winches far too weak to sustain constant use. 'Winch' is now an insult slung at lazy contractors across the Maelstrom.
Something meant for burrowing tunnels through loose sand near the surface probably should have taken the local wildlife into consideration. You're never alone out there. Never.

Billions of these went missing in the blink of an eye only a few years ago outside of a large shipping port, along with the captain of the cargo vessel that was transporting them. CH1-P is convinced the captain was the leader of a new brand of wormhole-loving thieves and who's to say she wasn't?

The colors alone indicate that this thing belonged to some important Dazaak council member. CH1-P warns Hasron not to try and take it off planet though as you never know who might be holding a grudge against their celestial neighbors.
Not much use for these on Talacan, but someone will buy it to take somewhere cold.
Hasron wonders for a moment how many years of life passed inside the pod, and shudders.

Now these were a disappointment. They were supposed to be the next big thing for the Maelstrom Cup a long while ago but never made it off the starting line in one piece. They've been blacklisted in legal races ever since.

Story goes that another scrapper once mistook these for some graphinium and snorted a small handful over a few minutes. She lived, but you could never tell who was calling the shots up there afterwards.
Destabilizing is just a fancy way of saying this thing used to be so loud it was banned from being used on any inhabited planet.
You could fit one of these in the palm of your hand, but then there wouldn't be much of a hand left after, would there?
This stuff would be worth a fortune if it had ever worked.
Hard to tell where half of these cooling units come from. At least this one looks to be in only a handful of pieces.
If you ever get off this rock you'll get tired of seeing these things real quick. But they're neat to look at the first thousand times or so.
If there were anything more left of this speeder, one of you would certainly recognize it. As it stands you're just glad whatever crashed in it is long gone.

Neither of you can figure out why this simple aluminum block has the common word "Sensor" written on every face of it. CH1-P presses each of their limbs against the form for a few minutes each. Nothing.
The nozzle might appear benign and agrarian, but Reed Industries has likely stolen more water than just about any other known corporation to supply their hydrofarms
You figure the outpost might be able to use this. Any orbital barrier needs a handful, and with so much scrap raining down, the outpost's barrier has been working overtime.
One of the old style, but something about the shape makes Hasron feel at home.

Hasron and CH1-P both privately wonder if there's anyway to convince the other to spend a few days trying to get this thing in orbit. If you don't make it to the Strom Race you'll need one of these things to tune in.
Discontinued only a few weeks after they hit the market because of a "feature" that sent the AI after their competitor's machines. A rare find, but be careful reactivating it around other drones.
Nothing is quite as loud as these if you can hear anything over 500,000 hz.
CH1-P is fascinated at the detail around the exit collar that you can see up close. In outer orbit you'd never get within optical range if you came up against something like this.
Great for a personal jump-jet or refrigerated backpack. Both at once seems doable, but you'd be hard pressed to find a mechanic insane enough to try it.
